org.factcenter.qilin.primitives

Interface RandomOracle

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    DigestOracle

    public interface RandomOracle
    Represents a Random Oracle. The Random Oracle is a theoretical construct that is an idealization of a cryptographic hash-function (it is equivalent to an ideal cipher). Although it is impossible to actually implement a Random Oracle, it is much easier to analyze in theoretical constructions, and consequently is used in many protocols. In most cases, we do not know how to break protocols that replace the Random Oracle with a secure cryptographic hash function (assuming the protocol is secure in the Random Oracle model). This interface Random Oracle is easy to use when both the position at which the random oracle is queried and the required output length are known in advance.
    See Also:
    StreamingRandomOracle

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int getNativeLength()
      Get the "native" length returned by a call to the digest function.
      byte[] hash(byte[] input, int outlen)
      Hash an arbitrary length input to an arbitrary length output.

    • Method Detail

      • hash

        byte[] hash(byte[] input,
            int outlen)
        Hash an arbitrary length input to an arbitrary length output.
        Parameters:
        input - the input to be hashed
        outlen - the number of bytes to return.
        Returns:
        the hashed input (an array of length outlen). If this method is called on the same input for two different output lengths, the output on the shorter length will be a prefix of the output on the longer.

      • getNativeLength

        int getNativeLength()
        Get the "native" length returned by a call to the digest function. Running hash(byte[], int) with this as the length value will be most efficient.
        Returns:
        the native length (in bytes)
